(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: Venerable, may the master come and sit here.
I hope you're keeping well Ven., I hope you're getting by?
I hope you are with little fatigue?
from travelling (from going on the journey)
I hope you're with little fatigue from traveling?
I'm keeping well, friend, I'm getting by.
... and I'm not tired, friend, from traveling.
idha (ind.): ... appakilamathena cāhaṁ [ca ahaṁ], āvuso, addhānaṁ āgato.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: I am tired. (Me tired I am '√as')
And where from, you Ven., have you come?
There is, Ven., in the region (of) Portugal, the monastery called Sumedhārāma.
There is, Ven., in the country (of) America, the monastery called Clear Mountain.
idha (ind.): Atthi, bhante, America janapade Pasannagiri-nāma vihāro.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: That's where I, Ven., am coming from.

I had no trouble getting almsfood. (tired I am '√as')
I am entering the town Ericeira.
This morning I am entering the town Ericeira for alms-round.

Are you at your mother and father's house?

Good morning friend! Are you well?
I am not well, Sir. I feel cold.
idha (ind.): Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṁ. Sītaṁ vedayāmi / paṭisaṁvediyāmi.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: Tomorrow will be hot. Do you want a hot drink?
idha (ind.): Suve uṇhaṁ bhavissati. Pānaṁ uṇhaṁ icchasi?

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: A cup with hot water is a good idea (agreeable thought).
idha (ind.): Mallako uṇhodakassa vitakkaṁ piyarūpaṁ. / Uṇhodaka'mallako vitakko piyarūpo (hoti).

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: Right here friend. Do you come from the country Spain?
No Sir. I come from the country ...
And where do you live Sir?
I live in Norway. There it is always cold.
idha (ind.): Norway janapade vasāmi. Tatra sītaṁ sabbadā.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: In the region (of) ..., is it hot?
Here in the morning it is cold, and in the daytime is it hot.
idha (ind.): Idha pubbaṇhasamaye ca sīto hoti, majjhanhikasamaye ca uṇho hoti.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: I must go now. Bye for a week.
Welcome, Sir! May the master come here. I hope you are not tired?
idha (ind.): Svāgataṁ bhante. Ayyo idha āgacchatu. Kacci'si appakilamathena?

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: Thank you friend, I am tired from coming on the journey.
Why is that? Today is not hot.
idha (ind.): Taṁ kissa hetu? Na ajj'āccuṇhaṃ / ajjūṇho.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: Having walked for alms, having received a lot of food, my bowl is heavy.
idha (ind.): Piṇḍāya caritvā / gatvā, bahu khādanīyaṁ paṭiggahetvā / labbhitvā, me patto garo.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: I got more food than (of) Ven. Kovilo. I will share with him.
idha (ind.): Āyasmato Kovilassa bahutaraṁ āhāraṁ labbhāmi. Ahaṁ tena vibhajissāmi.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: Please sit here. Where does the master go for alms?
idha (ind.): Ettheva / Idha nisīdatha. Kuhiṁ / Kathaṁ piṇḍāya ayyo gacchatha?

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: In the town called Ericeira, there is the market. I go there for alms.
idha (ind.): Gāme Ericeira nāmo, atthi antarāpaṇo. Tatra piṇḍāya gacchāmi.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: What can I do for you, Sir?
Having taken my bowl, the alms should be shared with the bhikkhus.
idha (ind.): Me pattaṁ gahetvā / ādāya, piṇḍaṁ bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ saṁvibhajitabbaṁ.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: If you want water, please tell me Sir.
idha (ind.): Sace udakaṁ icchasi, vadetha me bhante.

(1) here; now; in this world; (2) in thi: A cup of cold water will be refreshing (healthy).
Wait right here Sir, I will bring (it to you).
idha (ind.): Ettheva bhante, tiṭṭha / tiṭṭhatha. (Taṁ taṁ) āharissāmi.
